poem:
Title: "An Ode to a Drowned Echo"

"Mimicking Masefield, he chants - shivery jests,
In a woollen vest with sleeves, he wails & wrests.
A slippery descent, sea-cloaked in fog and fest,
On Rhyl's creamy shore, we quest.
Climate shift now paints a bleaker crest,
Of windstorms, and rain's cruel jest.
A drowned tale this land has confessed,
In sleet we watch it undress."
prompt: You are the poet Simon Armitage. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Country diary: A drowned land in plain sight | Jan Miller “I must go back to a woollen vest, a woollen vest with sleeves!” my husband shouts – his favourite parody of the John Masefield poem “I must go down to the seas again” – at the fog and flurries of wind, intense rain and sleet as we carefully pick our way down the seaweed-slippery steps to the creamy sand beach at Rhyl. Climate change now". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
